description: From Middle English navigate, from Latin nāvigō, from nāvis (“ship”) + agō (“do”), from Proto-Indo-European *néh₂us (“boat”).

verbs.description: navigate (third-person singular simple present navigates, present participle navigating, simple past and past participle navigated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To plan, control and record the position and course of a vehicle, ship, aircraft, etc., on a journey; to follow a planned course.
examples: He navigated the bomber to the Ruhr.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To give directions, as from a map, to someone driving a vehicle.
(intransitive) To travel over water in a ship; to sail.
examples: We navigated to France in the dinghy.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To move between web pages, menus, etc. by means of hyperlinks, mouse clicks, or any other mechanism.
examples: It was difficult to navigate back to the home page.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To find a way through a difficult situation or process.
